head.title: Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. - Page #18

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #18 of 32 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: being between 'em, shot them witht difficulty – then 1m. to another – shot it as the last – then ½m. to another being Portage neuf 520yds long on right side, & much incommoded for want of use, discharged a few pieces & past it easily – from the rapid turn'd upon the Lt – at the 1st pt is a rapid past it witht discharging – then ¾ to another went down easy 100yds to another, shot it as before, then 5¾ to the end of a swampy lac on each side the river, turn'd a pt on Rt & came to a Rapid which we shot abt ¼m. witht dischargg the remainder was a Port. for near all the Things, is on the right side, call'd Port. des Grosses Roches (by our men) 260yds over a good road, the men who shot the Canoe say it is difficult, from the Port. entd a small lac, across wch & into the river NW2m. then 2½ to a rapid, all debarked but 2 to shoot the Canoe, it is at least 3m. long & difficult in places, & call'd Rapid Croche, from hence ¾m. to ye rapid les trois Roches, this 3 rapids following each other very quick, past the first 2 witht debarking, but at the beging of the last, all debarked except 2 to shoot ye Canoe, distce of the whole abt ¾m. then ¾m. to another rapid called le Grosse Volante at least 3m. long with little breaks in places, exceeding strong Currt all ashore but 3 to shoot the Canoe, at the end of this a Cataract, which has a sloping descent over smooth rocks abt 20 feet. & call'd Chutte à Monataggè 100yds over a good road, on the Rt side of the Port. is a Channel, which leads into ye lac went thro' it abt 70yds, & then entd lac Monataggè – from the end of the Channel went WSW1m. to a Grassy pt on ye Rt – turn'd rod ye pt WNW3m. between 2 Is a large Stone in ye middle of the Chanl (which is narrow) from this ye lac appears spacious with isles to ye Rt – pass'd a wide bay on the Lt & a large Isld call'd Isle de Diable – the end of the Co is between is betw 2 islds NNW3½ – then turn'd ye Isld on Rt NW¼ across a bay to a pt on Lt sevl Islands on Rt from thence in a deep bay to a pt on the Rt NWbW1¼ pass'd 2 wide openings & sevl Islds on Lt – NWbW1¼ to a pt on Lt sandy beach on Rt & spacious on Lt then 1½NW. to a rocky pt of an Isld on Rt lac spacious & many Islds on both sides then NWbN2½ to a remarkable peek'd uneven rock on a pt on Rt lac spacious & many Islds on Lt – from the rock ½m. to a rocky pt on Lt deep bay on Rt – turn'd rod ye pt WbN1¼ to a pt on Rt sevl Isls on Lt & Isles & rocky uneven shore on Rt then cross[d] to the pt of an Isld 3½WNW – 4 bays on Rt & many Isls also Iss & spacious lac on Lt[,] then NWbW to a low rocky pt 1¼ being a narrow neck & rapid called rapid à la L'outre, bay & Iss on Rt spacious lac & Iss on Lt – from this pt shot ye rapid & entd another lac[.] (Encamp'd[.]) [T]his rapid is well stored with Poison dorèe, & white fish[.] Lac de Monataggè is the largest we have been in since we left lac Nippigon[,] is very full of Iss which makes the way rather difficult. As to the river we have left behind us to day I can say little in its favour. It is so very full of Islands Rapids, that it must be hurtful to Canoes & fatiguing to the men to go agt the Current, the line must be out 3 parts of the way, & if the water is high it will cover over the Stones on the Shore, which is the only way the men have to walk in[.] On the contrary the Portages are good in general, & tho' choak'd up with small woods, the Ground is dry & even, & the small woods may be soon clear'd away. One recommendation for this way I must mention is its shortness, which I am pretty certain by the Courses we have made, exceeds le chemin

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
